document.docAuthor: Neto, Carlos Santos, Nascimento, Elielton, Cavalcanti, Thaynã & Pinheiro, Ulisses
document.docTitle: Oceanapia hechteli Neto, Nascimento, Cavalcanti & Pinheiro, 2018, nom. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomy of Oceanapia Norman, 1869 (Demospongiae: Haplosclerida: Phloeodictyidae) from the Brazilian coast

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomy of Oceanapia Norman, 1869 (Demospongiae: Haplosclerida: Phloeodictyidae) from the Brazilian coast

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Adocia
sp. Hechtel, 1976 : p. 240 ( Pernambuco State, Brazil ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Rhizochalina nodulosa Hechtel, 1983
: p. 65, fig. 5–6 (Pernambuco State, Brazil).

Not
Oceanapia nodulosa ( Topsent, 1928 )
(a valid species).

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Material examined:
UFPEPOR 3172, off Recife Municipality ( 08°06’02’’S 34°42’07’’W ), Pernambuco State, Brazil , depth
30 m
, dredge, st. 129, Recife expedition,
5 April 1967
.

Comparative material: YPM 5705 ( Holotype ), Recife , Pernambuco State, Brazil , depth
27 m
, det. Hechtel (1983) ( Photographs of the specimen, choanosome and spicules).

subSubSection.paragraph:
External morphology ( Fig. 2A ).
Semispherical sponge, 9.3 x 6.2 cm (length x width). The specimen has nine fistulae, about 0.2–0.6 x 0.2–0.5 cm (length x width), distributed throughout the specimen. The surface is rough and hispid; firm consistency and circular oscules present at the top of the fistulae. Colour when preserved (ethanol 80%) is reddish brown, colour in life is unknown.

Skeleton ( Fig. 2B ).
Ectosoma multilayered compact crust of tangential spicules, with multispicular fiber bundles (69– 83.3 –102 µm, diameter). Cross-linked choanosomal skeleton with multispicular tracts (81– 107.7 –125 µm) forming well-defined circular meshes (125– 383.7 –625 µm).

Spicules ( Fig. 2C ).
Oxeas (174– 210.1 –232 / 6– 6.9 –8 µm): curved, smooth, robust and with telescopic tips. Raphidiform oxeas (97 –162.1– 230 / 2.6 µm): smooth, smaller and thinner.

Etymology. Named after George Hechtel, the authority who designed
Rhizochalina nodulosa Hechtel, 1983
.

Remarks. Hechtel (1983) described the species from a single specimen, the holotype ( YPM 5705), collected in Pernambuco State. We found a topotype specimen (UFPEPOR 3172), described herein. This specimen and the holotype have very similar features; both have a semispherical body with small fragmented fistulae. Their spicule complement of oxeas and its dimensions are similar (see Table 1 ).

About the homonymy
Oceanapia nodulosa , Topsent (1928)
described from the Azores a new species,
Phloeodictyon nodulosum
. Hechtel (1983) described the new species
Rhizochalina nodulosa
without observing that Van Soest (1980) had already proposed the genus
Rhizochalina
and
Phloeodictyon
as synonyms of
Oceanapia
. According to the International Code of Zoological Name (
ICZN 1999: 52.2
) the name
Oceanapia nodulosa ( Hechtel, 1983 )
should be rejected.
Oceanapia hechteli
nom. nov.
is herein proposed as a replacement for
Oceanapia nodulosa ( Hechtel, 1983 )
homonym of
Oceanapia nodulosa ( Topsent, 1928 )
.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Comparative micrometric data on the spicules, shape and distribution overview of
Oceanapia
species from Atlantic Ocean. Values are in micrometers (µm), expressed as follows: minimum–maximum or minimum– mean –maximum length/width. References are numbered in parentheses and listed after the table.

tr.td: Rio Grande do Norte State, Brazil / 211
Ovate body, fistulae on the top / Beige
Rio Grande do Norte State, Brazil / 108
Semispherical body with numerous digitated fistulae / Brown
Semispherical with few fragmented fistulae / Reddish brown

sensu Hechtel, 1983

nom. nov.
sensu Topsent, 1928

tr.td: Piriform with fragmented fistulae / Not recorded
Spherical, numerous fistulae on top / Beige
Semi incrusting base, cushion shape, fistulae projections / Red-brown
Basal mass which arise fistulae / Green (Ethanol)

tr.th:
Oceanapia bartschi sensu Lehnert & Van Soest 1999
5
tr.td: Vase shaped, numerous fistulae cover the surface / Blackish brown

6
tr.td: Globular, single larger central oscules / Not recorded
Globular with tubes projections / Not recorded
